author: @Hezron-Chaatazarawan
text:
In Gladiator 2, a slave could choose to be a gladiator or entertainer in hope to mitigate his captivity. This is an ancient take on modern day society. Black communities are groomed to believe, to overcome oppression, they must pursue a gladiator derivative(sports) or the entertainment industry(rap). This mindset was casted on black slaves to remain subject to higher powers, preventing revolution by altering a nation‚Äôs ambitions of becoming anything more than accepted.

‚ÄúA gladiator has his own money to spend‚Äù, stated Denzel‚Äôs character, Macrinus, while giving his gladiator money in exchange for his loyalty. When a slave receives privileges from his master, he is envied amongst his fellow servants. This strategy is utilized with black athletes of today who receive million dollar contracts, well adulated, yet, are nothing but paraded slaves running in tights and shorts for the appeasement of their white oppressors.

Ecclesiastes 7:7 Surely oppression maketh a wise man mad; and üëâüèæa gift destroyeth the heart.üëàüèæ

Every unrighteous man has a price. For money(gift) he will silence his mind(heart).

author: @ScottCommon632
text: gladiator 2?  no such thing.  it should never have been attempted.   at first i was too repulsed and i refused to watch it.  pure money grab.  And for Denzel to star in it only proved the weakness of the story / screenplay.  We all knew it.  But we had to see (and they knew it) training day meets Equalizer meets Rome.  Shame shame shame.  /// but then i couldn't help myself.... I knew it would be bad... but I had no idea how bad.  the worst casting,. some of the worst acting i've ever had to endure,... the most predictable and boring screenplay.  the movie barely stands on it's own merit.  were it not for the above average cinematography the movie would have been a worse flop to my senses.  and for to Denzel running around with his brilliant 2024 pearly white smile --- just gross: shame of casting and shame of him for desecrating the brand with his franchised now predictable gimmick acting (same dude in every movie).   and poor connie just cannot act: they should have un-alived her in the first part of the movie somehow.  The only way this movie could have possibly worked was a script written from a bold, more nuanced shakespearean way - less direct: but there was no way to accomplish this!  certainly this screenplay failed on every level.  Gladiator 2 should be a lesson to both producers, writers, actors and consumers: when the first is global box office and wins on so many levels... leave it alone: for the love of the arts,... leave it alone.

author: @Howlox
text:
I watched this and I liked it. But, what I will say is it can't hold a candle to the original. The plot is way too similar but doesn't make as much sense in this context, the CGI is decent at times (the rhino) and awful at other times (the monkeys that looks like demon or mutants).

But my absolutely least favourite thing was how hard it tried to reference the original, from them uttering the phrase "strength and honour" to him taking Maximus's armour and wearing it, him beheading a guy in the exact same way Maximus did (how'd he even remember Maximus doing that?), the movie using so much archive footage from the original, them shoehorning the plot that he had a son with Lucilla (despite the fact that it was not mentioned in the original and kinda undermines the themes of it), lots of shots mimicking the original, the son ordering the other slaves tactically in the exact way Maximus did, etc. etc. I really wish this movie tried harder to be its own thing.

author: @shivanichetty5430
text: This movie is very hard to pull off. Gladiator will forever be a masterpiece, never to be matched. Added to that, it holds too big a place in audiences' hearts. If this sequel referenced the first too little, it'd be a problem. It ended up doing it too much and totally fell in its shadow. And if it did hit a golden medium, the story would have to be incredible too. I still wanted Russell Crowe in it. He is such a HUGE part of what this franchise is and he's irreplaceable. Maybe the God's could have sent him back or something and then he lost his memory... only to regain it in a distant land. Then he returns to Rome, older of course, but now he wishes to achieve the dream of Marcus Aurelius. Then he meets Lucius and he has to train him... I could go on and on!!

author: @markdollard1084
text:
This is frustratingly close to being a great film; great cast, fantastic visuals and Ridley Scott on his best form in a decade.
Unfortunately, it's let down on all counts by the writing. Too many characters, practically all of them underwritten, are purely driven by plot motivation. Had it focused more on the relationship between mother and son, and less on imperialistic intrigue, it could have been on a par with it's predecessor.

text: Just saw the movie today and . . . it was so incredibly satisfying. Ridley Scott knows how to deliver on spectacle without sacrificing an incredibly moving story. My spouse was dabbling his eyes at the end, saying it was perfect. From the exciting opening naval scene, to the wild animals, and ferocious arena scenes, the way the original flashbacks tie into the current story is beautifully done. Denzel Washington was mesmerizing. Pedro Pascal played his role perfectly; I was wishing he had more screen time.  Paul Mescal delivered incredible fight physicality and heartbreaking pain. I loved it. Easily the best movie I‚Äôve seen in years.

author: @elhadi9886
text: I'm originally from the city of Caesarea (Cherchel), where Macrinus was born. It's a coastal city by the Mediterranean, and most of the people have white or tan skin. Even in the local museum, you can see statues, mosaics, and artifacts that show the people who lived there had predominantly white or tan features, not black. But personally, I think Denzel Washington is a great actor. I don't see any problem‚Äîwhite or black doesn't make a difference if the actor knows how to embody the character. And he did it perfectly.

author: @AryanAleviZaza
text:
Africa is not a homogeneous continent. North Africa, populated by Mediterranean-type populations, is clearly cut off from black Africa by the largest desert in the world: the Sahara. We cannot therefore say that all of Africa is a black continent
. You have to have a little common sense, a little logic so that the public can immerse themselves in the story. We cannot therefore choose, for example, a white actor like in the 50s and 60s to play, for example, the king of an African tribe, or a Chinese or Japanese emperor, whatever the talent of the actor in question, and the reverse is also true. It is a question of maintaining a minimum of coherence, especially when it is a film that deals with a historical period. It is true that for this film the problem does not stop only with the character of Denzel Washington and that Ridley Scott seems to have taken a lot of distance from historical reality (Gladiator had also taken some distance from history but despite all these "liberties" seemed credible and was counterbalanced by a powerful script rigor, which does not seem to be the case here). We are witnessing here an excessive Disneylandization, that is to say that we can do everything and its opposite without worrying about coherence and logic. Nothing matters, everything can be done and its opposite. It is no longer cinema but a circus, a huge show machine without a soul. You have to be devoid of culture and historical knowledge to find nothing wrong with it, maybe this film is aimed primarily at an American viewer.

The new cast is solid, 3 people are reprising their roles from the first one, it pays homage to the first one, and there's no ridiculous current day bullshit shoehorned into it (in the trailer at least). Which is already more than I would expect given Hollywood's dogshit trajectory the last decade.

I just expect better from someone like him, that's all...

author: @hhsamcox
text: After reading over 100 comments it's clear that some people are clearly invested in "whiteness" when the ancient Romans and Greeks at the time of the Gladiators were clearly an interethnic society. Why not interracial, because there is only one race, the human race, and what we know as "whiteness" is an invention of colonial America that went sideways over time. The ancient Greeks who founded so-called Western Civilization had no qualms about admitting that everything they knew was learned at the feet of Black/Kemetan scholars and scribes. Your Eurocentric educational system is being exposed for the indoctrination machine it is versus an accurate representation of historical world events. Grow up, Google the autobiographies of the ancient Greeks and Romans of history using the translation features available to everyone and see what the truth is. Can you handle it or do you need your fairy tales/lies/myths of whiteness to survive on a level playing field?!

text: Loved the original. The only movie I wanted to watch when I was home on leave in Iraq. Masterpiece. This other thing is not able to compete. Sadly for the rest of us, it ruins the original forever and dismantles Ridley Scott as a top director and show him more as a guy willing to sell his legacy off, not to mention his fans, and try for one more big blockbuster. text: Black people were central to Roman culture and held many roles, including emperors, soldiers, traders, philosophers, poets, dramatists, and theologians. Some say that Romans should be reimagined as having a variety of skin tones, and that Black people were not just slaves or servants. Harvard University Press's Blacks in Antiquity cites evidence from literary and archeological sources that shows Black Africans were known as warriors, diplomats, athletes, and performers, and were not primarily considered slaves.

text:
Now here me out‚Ä¶I think Gladiator II might surprise us
Here‚Äôs my way of thinking: Gladiator came out in 2000, Troy came out in 2004, 300 in 2006, 300: Rise of an Empire in 2014, if you had cable one of Starz‚Äôs most successful shows was Spartacus which went on for 4 seasons. So that‚Äôs why I think Gladiator II might surprise us. Was it necessary to make a sequel‚Ä¶no, but it sure is stirring up conversation and bringing the original back into the mix.
Then you have people like my mom who loves Pedro Pascal and has been a fan of Denzel Washington since he was on St. Elsewhere in the 80‚Äôs üòÇ

text: I will say what i did like about this trailer. The reveal of the coliseum being filled with water for fights between ships (i was really hoping if they made a sequel that they would do this), and the Rhino. If they had paired this trailer with a different, less off the wall song, and didnt overstuff it, it could have generated alot of excitement. The rap song and some of the dialog really undermined this trailer. Especially the rap song. Theres a reason why 90% of these comments are bashing this trailer over it. It shows hollywood desperately trying to make the trailer seem hip in the most misguided way possible. This is a movie about ancient rome for f*cks sake lol. author: @nmarks
text: In the clip we hear Lucius say that he never knew his mother or father, but in the original movie he most definitely knew both. It looks like following the death of Commodus,  there were tumultuous events in Rome, particularly among the elite; a lethal power grab in which either Lucilla told Lucius to go into hiding and deny who his parents were, or Lucius realised by himself he would have to, to survive. Lucius is, after all, the grandson of Marcus Aurelius and therefore descended from Roman Royalty.

author: @AlfredMontbank
text:
Rap to promote a classic Roman Empire movie? Really?
Would it make sense to play Techno music in the background in a film set up back in the old Maya society? Or some Flamenco music when presenting a Lord of the Rings film? What about either some soft Enya or some chill out music when presenting a action gang film?
Paramount Pictures, not a indie company, well established.
I believe any art may use some poetic license, to make greater the art itself, but not to the point it corrupts the art.
Do we ask ourselves how we come to this. Pushing and pushing something that doesnt make sense into becoming common, normal. I wont watch this film on cinema for sure. I am not paying and helping nonsense to spread. Maybe in few years I will watch it on one of the channels we already have.
Ps. I cant wait to see Last of the Mohicans 2, being presented maybe by some Reggea, or perhaps Rammstein? ü§£ü§£
